This game is a masterpiece.

Every aspect of Factorio is fantastic. When I first played it in 2018, the gameplay was really unique for me and I instantly fell in love. I know that today there are other factory building games, but for me, Factorio is the definitive one. There is literally no wrong way to play the game: you could, in theory, beat the base game by handcrafting every item! Obviously, it would take thousands of hours to do that, and this is why you automate. And automation is why this game is so challenging, addictive and satisfying. I played over a dozens of factories, and even with the blueprints from previous saved games, you always manage to build something new, find a better way to setup production, create more aesthetically pleasing blocks, and the list goes on. And because the world is basically infinite, you can keep scaling your factory to produce more and more (unfortunately I have never been able to build a mega factory, but a lot of people on Youtube have and there are some insane builds and factories). It's base building in its best.

The soundtrack is incredible. One of the best I have ever heard in videogames. The music is beautifully created and it fits so well with the world, which is visually very appealing and the best part is that it runs very well on low end PCs.

Factorio is one of those rare games that manages to combine simplicity of concept with extraordinary depth of execution. At its core, it‚Äôs a game about building a factory ‚Äî you start on an alien planet with nothing but your hands, and from those humble beginnings you end up constructing vast, fully automated production systems capable of manufacturing rockets, trains, and everything in between. But what makes Factorio special isn‚Äôt just what you build, it‚Äôs how you build it, and the satisfaction that comes from watching your intricate network of belts, inserters, and machines work in perfect synchronization.

What begins as a small operation quickly evolves into a sprawling industrial empire. The sense of progression is intoxicating ‚Äî each new technology unlocks not just another piece of machinery, but also new possibilities for optimization. The deeper you go, the more you realize that there‚Äôs always a better, faster, or more elegant way to organize your production lines. Players often describe the experience as ‚Äúaddictive‚Äù in the best way possible. One community member famously wrote, ‚ÄúI have 750 hours in Factorio and still haven‚Äôt touched the most popular mods.‚Äù That‚Äôs the kind of long-term engagement this game inspires.
If you like solving problems and building factories, then this game is what you want.

I can't stop.

a whispering in the whirring of machines, a voice in the static's crackle.

can't stop.

Grey concrete tendrils continents wide, stretching, grasping... clawing at the land, leaving her torn, then patching over and filling her lacerations, not a suture but a stent. Packing *Its* corruption into every crevice, every deformation, invading her depths. Engulfing her, devouring her, into *Itself* papering over all the devastation below. 
*It* will Never stop

Great game for anyone that loves solving logistical problems and math.

This game teaches you everything you need to know about software engineering without requiring you to write any code. It will teach you about technical debt, the cost of poor design, the costs of refactoring (or delaying refactoring), how to optimize and fix performance bottlenecks, how to build abstractions and think with them, how a less efficient but more scalable design can be much easier to manage than a bespoke optimized design, etc.

It might not sound it, but the game is very fun. You're managing the complexity of this massive factory you're creating while trying to keep bugs that don't like you at bay. It is very addictive for people with a certain type of personality. It scratches an itch for people who like to build and optimize. It even has some optional logic "programming" stuff (like a Zachtronics game) in it if that suits your fancy. It's also a pretty cool game if you like trains. Choo-choo!

An incredible, intricate game with unbelieveable freedom and complexity, Whilst the space age expansion was good it was really challenging to wrap your head around at times and the lack of too much guidance made the puzzle quite fun but painful. In general though it created a lot of gameplay and challenges I generally really enjoyed

Hours Played: 4,000+ (and counting)

Factorio is, without exaggeration, one of the most fun and compelling games I‚Äôve ever touched. After more than four thousand hours, I still find myself saying ‚Äújust one more improvement‚Äù at 3 a.m. ‚Äî and somehow the game always finds another way to pull me deeper in.

The core gameplay loop is absolutely brilliant. Designing factories, optimizing layouts, solving logistical puzzles, managing power, and building ever-larger production lines feels endlessly satisfying. Every improvement you make ripples through the whole system, and watching your base grow from a tiny burner setup into a planet-spanning industrial machine never gets old.

Then there‚Äôs the defense. Biters might be the best uninvited guests in gaming ‚Äî always pushing you to adapt, upgrade, and reinforce your perimeter. Balancing expansion with defense keeps every run engaging.

I‚Äôve always loved designing train networks, logistic systems, and custom blueprints, and Factorio delivers in a way no other game does. Creating a perfectly timed, perfectly routed train system is practically an art form.

And now? The Space Age expansion took all of that and added even more fun. New worlds, exploration, new challenges to overcome on every planet ‚Äî it expands Factorio in exactly the right way. Your factory doesn‚Äôt just grow outward anymore; it grows upward and outward across an entire solar system.

Every time I think I‚Äôve seen it all, Factorio proves me wrong.

If you enjoy building, problem-solving, logistics, automation, trains, or just want to lose yourself in the most satisfying ‚Äúone more thing‚Äù cycle ever created, you owe it to yourself to play Factorio ‚Äî and Space Age makes it even better.
